zuul/lib/keystorage.py.message: Good point; we should get that information into stderr.
Might want to record that the walk and consequently the export had errors somewhere? That way operators can see the export may have problems that need to be addressed?
Having a force flag might be a good idea here so that users can avoid restoring from a stale backup?

To be clear: are you suggesting that the default mode should be to refuse to overwrite existing keys in ZK, and then only if --force is added, then we would allow that?

(Note that at the moment there is not yet a way to delete all the keys from ZK, but that's on the to-do list).

Yes. In my mind there are two ways you hit this exception. The first is the one that is handled fine which is where we overwrite data with identical data because you are restoring what is already there. The other is if a project's secrets update for whatever reason and then you restore from backup you probably don't want it to implicitly overwrite what was there.

Instead, you should be given the option to say "no I really want the old stuff because the new stuff is bad".

zuul/scheduler.py.message: Writing a separate file for each record isn't a regression on how it was working before. I wonder if it might be simpler for users to have an aggregated serialization of some sort. Like a list of objects in a single json file ?

I'm open to this idea.

Another thought that occured to me from this is it might be nice to keep checksums of the individual bits of data and having things split out into files like that might make that easier? Then you know what specific thing is corrupted if that happens rather than the entire dataset and needing to sift through it.

I think I'm on board with that idea -- but if this container is supposed to exist (and especially if it's supposed to have data in it!) it makes me nervous that we'd lose what little signal we've got that the system is in this inconsistent state.

Even the dark data watcher won't help -- since it's using direct_client, it never checks for account existence :-/

Unfortunately it's not a little signal for me. People are losing their marbles in RH Bugzilla.

If you want, I can leave the updater flopping around as it hits 404 again and again. It just made no sense to me.

If it's a normal cluster, this is not happening. If it's a deployment orchestration unrolling Swift over dirty volumes (as usually the case that triggers the bug), then nobody reads the logs. They only get alerted to the account server tracebacking. So the result is, you still have exact same dark data already: it's not anchored at the account, so it's dark. So stubbing the updater like my patch does does not actually make it any worse, surprisingly enough.

stx-cert-manager-helm/stx-cert-manager-h.message: When this is enabled, does "kubectl certificate get" show the owner of the certificate? Anyway to tell the "ownership" of the certificate from a CLI? Or this is just a cert-manager internal configuration arg?
Thanks Mich. I'm fine with your answer. This also clarifies my understanding about this flag.

Hi Andy, I find myself unable to discern the direction of your question.  Literally, no this command does not show owner of the certificate: "kubectl get certificate -n vault".

The documentation for the --enable-certificate-owner-ref option does not describe ownership, but there is a owner ref in the description of certificate request.  The documentation emphasises that a service may continue to use the certificate after certificate resource is deleted:
https://cert-manager.io/docs/usage/certificate/

Here are some excerpts of the kubectl describe command for vault certificaterequests and certficates (I'm omitting a lot of text).  There is "owner references" in the describe output which is probably where that phrasing comes from in the bug description and quoted in git log:

# kubectl get certificaterequests -n vault
NAME                          READY   AGE
vault-server-tls-2006703579   True    20h

# kubectl describe certificaterequests/vault-server-tls-2006703579 -n vault
Name:         vault-server-tls-2006703579
API Version:  cert-manager.io/v1alpha3
Metadata:
  Owner References:
    API Version:           cert-manager.io/v1alpha2
    Block Owner Deletion:  true
    Controller:            true
    Kind:                  Certificate
    Name:                  vault-server-tls
    UID:                   0827566f-77f8-4299-843b-b3bd2d77f0c8
Spec:
  Issuer Ref:
    Group:  cert-manager.io
    Kind:   Issuer
    Name:   ca-issuer
  Usages:
    server auth
    client auth

# kubectl describe certificates/vault-server-tls -n vault
Name:         vault-server-tls
API Version:  cert-manager.io/v1alpha3
Metadata:
  UID:               0827566f-77f8-4299-843b-b3bd2d77f0c8
Spec:
  Issuer Ref:
    Group:        cert-manager.io
    Kind:         Issuer
    Name:         ca-issuer
  Secret Name:    vault-server-tls

The Certificate resource will be the owner of the CertificateRequest and Secret resources created by the Certificate. When you have this flag enabled, the child resources (CertificateRequest, Secret) will have the ownerRef field pointing to the Certificate.

ironic/conductor/manager.py.message:
Truthfully this kind of makes me a little uneasy, but I'm not sure of a better way to *really* handle it in some cases.  Think the driver may support it, but the hardware doesn't. A good example of this difference is Power hardware where there the boot design/process is much more along the lines of uefi by design, but there is no qualfier, no config, no override, it boots in it's own way and it has does so that we kind of mentally think of it as "legacy bios". So if we try to set it to uefi, it won't work, if we set it to bios, I think it might, but that is only because bios is implied by the setting we send it over IPMI. For what it is worth, afaik, power hardware does not support redfish or any of the vendor specific drivers.

I guess no action is really required here, just thinking outloud.

I agree. I was also concerned but moreso in the reverse direction. As in - What if some special boot mode is supported that's not termed strictly either 'uefi' or 'bios'? 
In that case if the driver doesn't provide the list of supported boot modes, this list may be too restrictive and api callers wont be able to access those hypothetical other modes.

One way to resolve this is just respect what the user wants to do, go ahead and try to set the boot mode and let the user deal with what happens later 🙃.
It's asynchronous, so shouldn't block either way (?)
The RFE comments mention it's sort of a raw command, Maybe it's expected that we don't reject stuff?

Is this a better way to do this,
Or the alternative way currently shown in conductor/utils? :
    ``supported_boot_modes = ()``
    # which thus skips the check below if driver doesn't explicitly return supported boot modes.

The api already filters out invalid values, so checking against explicit values may not even be required here?

cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/s.message:
I'm not clear how this fixes the problem described in the bug.  What the old code was supposed to be doing is check to see if value is in rel_info, and if so, update the metadata.  So why not just check this:

  if value in rel_info:

'Sync' is one of the replicatoin parameters which behaves differently compared to others.
possible values for the parameter in SVF are 'outofsyc', '' (empty in case of full synched volume).

Consider a case where sync is updated with 'outofsync' initially and next refresh metadata would fetch it as ''(empty). if we restrict empty values of sync atribute. it will never be updated.
only "sync" attribute's value will be empty or is it possible that any other attribute's value can be empty?

(1) It would be helpful to have a comment here about how 'sync' behaves so that it's clear why this is being checked, and also (as indicated in your answer to Girish) that you are intentionally ignoring any other parameters that have an empty string as a value.

(2) More importantly, however, this condition is not correct.  Suppose
  rel_info['sync'] == ''

Then the right side of the disjunction will never be checked in any iteration of the loop, and if the value is not a key in rel_info, you will get a KeyError at line 3388.  And if the value *is* a key but has an empty value, then you'll be setting it in the metadata, contrary to what you said you're supposed to be doing.  (This also indicates that your unit test is not very robust, because you did not detect this yourself.)

(3) Further, the problem with line 3387 in the base patch is, as you say, that if rel_info.get(value) returns an empty string, the condition is False.  That's why I suggested only checking to see
  if value in rel_info:

because the above condition only looks at whether the key (which is confusingly named 'value' here) is there or not.  This way you know there will be no key errors when you access rel_info[value] later, and you can take that into account in checking whatever needs to be checked to get this correct.

Thanks Brian for detailed analysis, we agree that condition is wrong.

we have analyzed all the parameters of lsrcrealtionship in the storage, there can be other attributes which can empty at some point of time.
For few attributes like sync, even the empty value indicates successful synchronization.

It is better to remove the line 3387 completely so that the attributes data from the storage is updated as it is, without any 'empty' checks.

This would also need change in commit message, release notes, and UT.

glance/api/v2/policy.py.message:
Unless I'm missing something, the default policy for deactivate and reactivate is "rule:default" which resolves to "". That means anyone can do it according to the policy we have and are shipping today. I think we've buried some bespoke enforcement in the onion layers (potentially just the "only owner can modify") which makes this not actually a thing, but I think the test failure on this patch is exposing that fact at the moment. The test is depending on the fact that TENANT2 can't de/reactivate the image, but that's actually just because they don't own it, not because they fail the policy check.

This is another good reason not to have hard-coded checks for these things, and not to have one policy check imply the other. Operators could have totally broken policy that doesn't expose something because there is some implied additional check, but if something changes in the order or method of enforcement, suddenly they're allowing people to do things they don't intend. So in this case, someone taking the default policy is literally saying "anyone can de/reactivate anyone else's image" according to the rules, and we're only preventing it because of the hard-coded "only owner can do anything" check, which needs to change anyway.

Adding this:

https://termbin.com/rjen

Makes this test pass for me, and is probably what we need to do. TBH, it looks like maybe the defaults for a lot of operations are defaulting to "anyone can do anything" and the only thing that is preventing that today is the hard-coded "only owner" layer :/

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ku.message:
It's important to notice how this audit method is working: it detects if the current docker registry credentials is different from "registry-local-secret". If this occurs, then it updates all secrets. 

In other words, it is able detect that the docker registry system credentials changed (testing against "registry-local-secret"), but it does not detect if any docker registry secret changed. It assumes that all docker registry secrets were created correctly and weren't changed.

After an AIOSX deploy, the docker registry secrets are the ones listed below.

name default-registry-key,  namespace armada
name default-registry-key,  namespace cert-manager
name default-registry-key,  namespace deployment
name default-registry-key,  namespace kube-system
name registry-local-secret, namespace kube-system

It was verified that the values of secrets of namespaces "armada" and "kube-system" are different from the other secrets (they have extra unused fields created during deploy), and that suggests the code that update docker registry secrets never run after system boot (the condition "secret_auth_info == base64.b64encode(registry_auth_info)" at line 995 is always true, as the sysinv username and password don't change, and the method returns at line 997).

We can simplify this by using json.dumps instead:

```
>>> '{{\"auths\": {{\"{0}\": {{\"auth\": \"{1}\"}}}}}}'.format("foo", "bar")
'{"auths": {"foo": {"auth": "bar"}}}'
>>> json.dumps({"auths": {"foo": {"auth": "bar"}}})
'{"auths": {"foo": {"auth": "bar"}}}'
```
Thanks for pointing out this enhancement, Rafael, but as the code was already well tested as it is, I'll leave this change for the future.

Suggestion: 

The whole method is being try-except by this single try.
It would be better to focus the use of try-except where it matters. 

Since the whole method is being try-except, I see no reason why there are other try-except.

It is possible to use try-except-else so you could use try in a single statement known to throw exceptions, except will catch exception and else will follow the execution if no exception happens. This reduces the amount of nested try-except in the code.

The intention of this implementation is to fix the maximum number of secret values even if there is an exception during the analysis of one specific secret. This is why there are nested try-catch here. Example: in line 1020, "self._kube.kube_get_service_account" can raise an exception but we want continue the analysis of other secrets.
It would be interesting to log when sa is None, just for debugging reasons. Otherwise it is not possible to know when secret_name is found or when sa is None.
I'll add an warning message when sa was not found, as it is not expected to have the 'trident' namespace ('if' of line 1018) while not having the 'trident-csi' present.

Why is this being try-except since the whole block is already catching any exception ? If it is because of the log messages, you could replace the call of LOG.error in here by setting a log message that will be displayed by the outer except block.

This serves for other try-except inside this method.
I agree with you that this try-except is not essential, as the one in line 1019 serves the purpose. It will be removed.
Is this namespace for a specific application?  If so, shouldn't the code to query any secrets specific to that application be in the application plugin rather than in the core sysinv code?
After talking further, the trident code isn't actually a sysinv "application" so there's no plugin.
arguably these aren't so much "custom" as "additional ones beyond the default secret name".  Might make sense to remove the "custom_" from the variable names.

Could we use static IP translation with 5 tuple (src_mac, dest_mac, src_ip, dest_ip, protocol_port) to do NATing without involved with kernel ct? ct may not be supported well with smart-NIC. But static NATing can be offloaded smoothly. So firstly we need some data change, Local IP should add a protocol port attributed.

Then this will be:
1. packet from <fa:16:3e:5c:3b:XX, 10.0.0.X, TCP_10000> to <10.0.0.10 TCP: 80>
2. change packet from
< dest_mac: fa:16:3e:5c:3b:4b  dest_IP: 10.0.0.10>
to < dest_mac: fa:16:3e:5c:3b:4b  dest_IP: 10.0.0.51 >
and learn flows: 
(from <src_mac: fa:16:3e:5c:3b:4b src_IP: 10.0.0.51 TCP_src: 80  dest_MAC: fa:16:3e:5c:3b:XX + 10.0.0.XX, TCP_dest 10000> to <src_MAC: fa:16:3e:5c:3b:4b src_IP: 10.0.0.10 > output: tap56fbc1e7-2c )

Learn back flows with 7 tuple (src_mac, dest_mac, src_ip, dest_ip, protocol, src_protocol_port, dest_protocol_port), protocol can be limitted to TCP and UDP only. Some flows can be:
match dest_mac + dest_ip + TCP/UDP, action: set dest_ip -> 10.0.0.51, learn (match <src_mac, dest_mac, src_ip, dest_ip, protocol, src_protocol_port, dest_protocol_port> ... output:XXX)

Cloud you add a section which describes the packet processing details? Something like this:

VM1 <10.0.0.100> try to access 10.0.0.10, it will be direct to 10.0.0.51:

ARP:
VM1 -> ARP -> 10.0.0.10 and response <10.0.0.10 has MAC_2>

egress:
<VM1_MAC_1 + 10.0.0.100> to <MAC_2 + 10.0.0.10>
ct NAT
<VM1_MAC_1 + 10.0.0.100> to <MAC_2 + 10.0.0.51>


Ingress(back):

<MAC_2 + 10.0.0.10> to <<VM1_MAC_1 + 10.0.0.100>

that may be tricky in some cases, like e.g.:

1. there is vm with local IP address on node and it works fine,
2. there is additional vm with same local IP migrated to that node (maintenance of other node maybe) - now still older vm should serve local IP, not the one which was migrated to that node,
3. now older vm is migrated to other node - You will need to update all configuration to make vm migrated in point 2 to serve local IP address on that node from now on.

As there is no way to identify which port was first on the node (or is there?) and also order of port list returned by server to agent is not deterministic - I'd prefer to document this as limitation (in first version at least). An assumption (maybe a weak one but still) is that VMs with assigned local IP will provide same service so local clients will not notice the change.
Documenting that should be ok, thx

Yeah, speaking about local IPs GRE should work same as VxLAN. I'll update

deployment/logging/rsyslog-container-pup.message: would it be better to rephrase this to "package" ? IIUC this is not removing only service but the whole package providing that service.

we should use the systemd module

  - name: Disable fluentd
    systemd:
      name: fluentd
      enabled: no
      state: stopped

there's no need to do any of this. However, if you want to do the test for the unit file before calling the systemd module we can do the following.

            - name: Check if fluentd is deployed on the host
              command: systemctl is-enabled --quiet fluentd
              failed_when: false
              register: fluentd_enabled_result
            - name: Stop and disable fluentd service
              systemd:
                name: fluentd
                state: stopped
                enabled: no
              when:
                - fluentd_enabled_result.rc == 0

Which will get rid of the extra fact.
shall we not ensure we have the service first? IIRC systemd module fails in case we mention an unknown unit.
